---
title: Prepared Queries
slug: en/v1/guides/prepared-query
---

## Basic Usage

The basic example of using prepared queries is as follows:

```ts
import { surql, Surreal, Thing } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb";

const CreateUserQuery = surql`CREATE ONLY user:foo CONTENT { age: 42 };`
  .returns<[{ id: Thing<"user">, age: number }]>();

const db = new Surreal();
await db.connect(`ws://localhost:8000`);
await db.signin({ user: "root", pass: "root" });
await db.use("example", "example");

const results = await db.query(CreateUserQuery);
//    ^? const results: [{ id: Thing<"user">, age: number }]

await db.disconnect();
```

Preparing the query enables type inference. However, the inferred type must be set manually.

## Validating Query Results

Queries become safer when you provide a validator for the query result in the `.returns` argument. The following example uses Zod to verify that the query result is the intended value:

```ts
import { surql, Surreal, Thing } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb";
import { z } from "zod";

const isUserTable = (id: Thing): id is Thing<"user"> => id.tb === "user";

const CreatedUserSchema = z.tuple([
  z.object({
    id: z.instanceof(Thing).refine(isUserTable),
    age: z.number(),
  }),
]);

const CreateUserQuery = surql`CREATE ONLY user:bar CONTENT { age: 42 };`
  .returns(CreatedUserSchema.parse.bind(CreatedUserSchema));

const db = new Surreal();
await db.connect(`ws://localhost:8000`);
await db.signin({ user: "root", pass: "root" });
await db.use("example", "example");

const results = await db.query(CreateUserQuery);
//    ^? const results: [{ id: Thing<"user">, age: number }]

await db.disconnect();
```

You are not limited to using Zod. You can verify responses using Valibot or general-purpose functions.

## Embedding Variables into Queries

`surql` allows you to write queries with template literals, making it possible to visually embed values:

```ts
import { surql, Surreal, Thing } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb";

const USERNAME = "baz";
const USER_AGE = 42;

const CreateUserQuery = surql`
  CREATE ONLY type::thing('user', ${USERNAME}) CONTENT { age: ${USER_AGE} };`
  .returns<[{ id: Thing<"user">; age: number }]>();

const db = new Surreal();
await db.connect(`ws://localhost:8000`);
await db.signin({ user: "root", pass: "root" });
await db.use("example", "example");

const results = await db.query(CreateUserQuery);
//    ^? const results: [{ id: Thing<"user">, age: number }]

await db.disconnect();
```

The parameters of the RPC request sent in the above example are as follows:

```text
CREATE ONLY type::thing('user', $_jst_0) CONTENT { age: $_jst_1 };
```

```ts
{
  _jst_0: "baz",
  _jst_1: 42
}
```

## Defining Arguments for Queries

Use `surql.slot` to define arguments for a prepared query:

```ts
import { surql, Surreal, Thing } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb";
import { z } from "zod";

const isUserTable = (id: Thing): id is Thing<"user"> => id.tb === "user";

const UserIdSchema = z.instanceof(Thing).refine(isUserTable);

const UserIdSlot = surql.slot("id")
  .type(UserIdSchema.parse.bind(UserIdSchema));

const UserAgeSlot = surql.slot("age", 42);

const CreateUserQuery = surql`
  CREATE ONLY ${UserIdSlot} CONTENT { age: ${UserAgeSlot} };`
  .returns<[{ id: Thing<"user">; age: number }]>();

const db = new Surreal();
await db.connect(`ws://localhost:8000`);
await db.signin({ user: "root", pass: "root" });
await db.use("example", "example");

const results = await db.query(CreateUserQuery, {
  id: new Thing("user", "tai-kun"),
});

await db.disconnect();
```

Slots require a variable name. The `.type()` method allows you to constrain the variable at the type level. Similar to `.returns()`, you can provide a function to validate values in the `.type()` argument. In the above example, the slot with the variable name `id` must be a record ID with a table name of `"user"`.

You can set a default value after the variable name in the slot argument. If the slot's variable name is omitted at runtime, this default value will be used. In the above example, the slot with the variable name `age` is set to the default value `42`.

In addition to `.type()`, slots have other methods such as `.rename()`, `.default()`, `.optional()`, and `.required()`.

If a prepared query contains a slot that requires the specification of a variable at runtime, it will be rejected at runtime with `SurrealTypeError` if it is unspecified. If the type is inferred correctly in TypeScript, you will get an error at the type level without running the query. For example, the following code will cause an error during type checking with `tsc` if you omit the required variable:

```ts
import { surql, Surreal, Thing } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb";

const UserIdSlot = surql.slot("id")
  .type<Thing<"user">>();

const UserAgeSlot = surql.slot("age", 42);

const CreateUserQuery = surql`
  CREATE ONLY ${UserIdSlot} CONTENT { age: ${UserAgeSlot} };`
  .returns<[{ id: Thing<"user">, age: number }]>()

const db = new Surreal();
await db.connect("ws://localhost:8000");

const results = await db.query(CreateUserQuery, {
  // id: new Thing("user", "tai-kun"),
});

await db.disconnect();
```

`npx tsc --noEmit`:
